definitions.definition: to make an opening or a wound in something, especially with a sharp tool such as a knife or scissors
definitions.sensetop: cut somethingcut somebody/yourselfcut something + adj.cut into somethingcut through something

examples.text: She cut her finger on a piece of glass.
He cut himself *(= his face)* shaving.
Sometimes people experiencing distress cut themselves *(= deliberately)*.
She had fallen and **cut** her head **open**.
She picked up the knife and cut into the meat.
You need a powerful saw to cut through metal.
The canoe cut through the water.

definitions.definition: to divide something into two or more pieces with a knife, etc.

examples.text: Don't cut the string—untie the knots.
The bus **was cut in two** by the train.
Now **cut** the tomatoes **in half**.
He cut the loaf into thick slices.
She cut the loaf in two and gave me one of the halves.
Make sure you cut the bread nice and thick.
I'll cut the apple in half.
He cut the bread into thin slices.
She cut the cake into six pieces.
Cut the carrots in half lengthwise.
Cut the courgette in half lengthways.
Cut the stem cleanly, just beneath a leaf joint.

definitions.definition: to make something shorter by cutting

examples.text: She **cuts hair** for a living.
to cut the grass/lawn/hedge
the smell of freshly cut grass
He's **had his hair cut** really short.
I'm going to get/​have my hair cut really short.
Her hair had been very well cut.
I told the stylist I wanted my hair cut short.

definitions.definition: to remove something or a part of something, using a knife, etc.
definitions.sensetop: cut somethingcut something from somethingcut somebody somethingcut something for somebody

examples.text: First, cut a long piece of string.
He cut four thick slices from the loaf.
a bunch of cut flowers
I cut them all a piece of birthday cake.
I cut a piece of birthday cake for them all.
freshly cut flowers
Shall I cut you a piece of cake?

definitions.definition: to make or form something by removing material with a knife, etc.
definitions.sensetop: cut something in somethingcut something into somethingcut something

examples.text: Workmen **cut a hole** in the pipe.
The climbers cut steps in the ice.
home-made biscuits cut into heart shapes
Cut a circle of waxed paper to fit the bottom of the pan.

definitions.definition: to be capable of cutting

examples.text: This knife won't cut.

definitions.definition: to be capable of being cut

examples.text: Sandstone cuts easily.

definitions.definition: to reduce something by removing a part of it
definitions.sensetop: cut somethingcut something by…cut something to…cut something from… to…

examples.text: to **cut costs/prices/spending/taxes**
Buyers will bargain hard to **cut the cost of** the house they want.
a plan to drastically **cut emissions**
His salary has been cut by ten per cent.
The Bank of England has **cut interest rates** to 1.5 per cent.
Could you cut your essay from 5 000 to 3 000 words?
We have managed to cut our costs drastically.
The department has to cut its spending by 30 per cent.
The price has been cut from €250 to €175.
The President has promised to cut taxes significantly.

definitions.definition: to allow somebody to escape from somewhere by cutting the rope, object, etc. that is holding them

examples.text: The injured driver had to be cut from the wreckage.
Two survivors were **cut free** after being trapped for twenty minutes.

definitions.definition: to design and make a piece of clothing in a particular way

examples.text: The swimsuit was cut high in the leg.

definitions.definition: to remove something from something

examples.text: This scene was cut from the final version of the movie.

definitions.definition: to delete (= remove) part of a text on a computer screen in order to place it somewhere else

examples.text: You can **cut and paste** between different programs.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody to stop doing something

examples.text: Cut the chatter and get on with your work!

definitions.definition: to completely end a relationship or all communication with somebody

examples.text: She has cut all ties with her family.
He has refused to cut links with these companies.

definitions.definition: to prepare a film or tape by removing parts of it or putting them in a different order
to stop filming or recording

examples.text: The director shouted ‘Cut!’

definitions.definition: to move quickly from one scene to another

examples.text: The scene cuts from the bedroom to the street.

definitions.definition: to stay away from a class that you should go to

examples.text: He's always **cutting class**.

definitions.definition: to hurt somebody emotionally

examples.text: His cruel remarks cut her deeply.

definitions.definition: to divide a pack of playing cards by lifting a section from the top, in order to reveal a card to decide who is to play first, etc.

examples.text: Let's cut for dealer.

definitions.definition: to cross another line

examples.text: The line cuts the circle at two points.

definitions.definition: to have a new tooth beginning to appear through the gum

examples.text: When did she cut her first tooth?

definitions.definition: to make a sound recording on a record, CD, etc.

examples.text: The Beatles cut their first disc in 1962.

definitions.definition: to mix an illegal drug such as heroin with another substance
to make a quick or sudden escape
to (not) be as good as is expected or needed

examples.text: He won't cut it as a professional singer.

wordOrigin: Middle English (probably existing, although not recorded, in Old English); probably of Germanic origin and related to Norwegian kutte and Icelandic kuta ‘cut with a small knife’, kuti ‘small blunt knife’.
